posts.post_content:
Goes well with a new card from Gatecrash: [Enter the Infinite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Enter the Infinite) (Draw your whole deck, put one card back, no max hand size).   
So what you do is cast Enter the Infinite. Next turn do the following:  
1) Draw last card  
2) Tap 7 lands, cast [Jokulhaups](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jokulhaups)  
3) Cast [Tormod's Crypt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tormod's Crypt)  
4) Cast One with Nothing  
5) Sac the crypt targeting yourself (note that it will be in the graveyard and exile itself)  
  
Result: No cards in hand, library, graveyard or in play. You have become completely one with nothing. Imagine the looks on your opponent's faces! Then reality sinks in, and they realize that they have to keep playing, and they have nothing left in play either...

posts.post_content:
Me and my friend created a new game format among our friends.  
  
It's called Duel for Nothing.   
  
What happens is that you play a game with any deck size.   
  
You then replace 4 cards of your deck with One with Nothing. If you want to try it in EDH, still include 4 One with Nothing's.  
  
If you have One with Nothing if your hand at ANY moment (opening hand or your draw it or you tutor for it (why? You tell me!)) you MUST play it. It is uncounterable, and costs ![0](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=0&type=symbol).   
  
It will be a cruel game of, "Oh yeah! All I need is one land, and... NNNOOO!!!!".   
  
Then, and ONLY THEN will you ever experience being One with Nothing

posts.post_content:
I don't think it's that they actively sought to make it rare, but really, what else *could* it be? That sense of disbelief you get when you see it, the sputtering and slack-jawed, open-mouthed wonder that steals over you...it is not rare for its power, but rather for its power to infuriate you if you open it.  
  
One With Nothing, thank you for having the cojones to be different, challenging, and above all INFURIATING. 5/5

posts.post_content:
This is by far the worst card ever to see play in a modern Pro Tour. Ironically, it was used to combat the Owling Mine deck, a deck WotC didn't even know existed.  
  
Of course, the best players just played zoo, which rendered the matchup unwinnable for Owling Mine, but for those who didn't, this card came in handy in what was the dumbest answer to any deck ever.

Posted By: Riclamin (4/26/2013 9:16:20 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't get how this is rated so low, this is a black card people. Think about it. Turn 2, cast 2 dark riturals. Cast a tutor, then cast this in response. Empty the Eldrazi out of your hand. Tutor animate dead. And there is your Eldrazi turn 2 plus a whole not more cards in the grave you could use later. This is the ultimate play from the grave card.   
  
It's also a great counter to [Balance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Balance) and any card that makes players have the same hand size or draw the same number of cards you have, and since it's block like I said you can play your cards from the grave they most likely can't.   
  
And "One with Absolutely Nothing," would be the most broken card ever made. There are cards that bring every creature from your grave into play, and cards that bring every enchantment and artifact from your grave into play, you know that right? As long as you can give you creatures haste which would be super easy, you would win the game that turn.

posts.post_content:
This card bugs the hell out of me for being at the wrong rarity, and I'm not talking about power.  
  
Think about it. This card could be three things: Rare, Uncommon, or Common (disregarding Mythic for now, wasn't around then and couldn't be one anyway due to the power level).  
  
As a Rare, it annoys people who get it since it's so brutally narrow - very effective in the right decks, but does bugger all for most others. Could've been a much cooler or more interesting card from that set, but sadly this is not the case. People who do want it will struggle to get a lot too, as it's a rare (unless you buy online).  
  
As a common, you'd be have loads of these and it would have no useful purpose whatsoever in the draft scene, especially in a pure Saviours draft (auto-correct won't let me spell it the heretical American way). It'd just be a weird card you'd see loads of.  
  
But at Uncommon? You'd get maybe one or two, you'd still have your shiny rare, and you wouldn't be overloaded with them. You coul... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Rating:

posts.post_content: This card does not suck. You're all just hating on it because you're embarrassed about flaming the hell out of it, then 'oops!' looks like someone discovered it's actually completely abusable. This warrants 3 stars at a minimum for teaching everyone to never mock an innocuous so blindly again. Yes, the particular thing this card does can be done better by some other things...but few cards influenced the way people thought about cards in general more than this one. One With Nothing let the cat out of the bag: the wierd cards are awesome, and you should get all the copies your snooty dumb buddies turn their noses up at, because you never know what's going to be the next [Memory Jar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Memory Jar). It was not the first to shape people's thought's: it joins the noble ranks of [Necropotence](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Necropotence), [Doubling Season](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doubling Season), [Morphling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Morphling), [Lightning Bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Bolt), and I'm having difficulty thinking of others that really defined as en... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
